prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For having a sleepover with my (21M) friend (22F) and not asking my girlfriend (20F)?
Title is pretty self explanatory but here goes.

One of my closest friends at uni, Annie (who is in a long term relationship) came over one night to have a couple of drinks before heading to a party. One of our friends bailed and we didn’t want to go to the party alone so we watched TV and smoked a couple of Js. The TV is in my room and we fell asleep together. 

My girlfriend of 2 years was at a concert with a girl friend at the time and since we had decided not to go to the party anymore went back to her place instead of coming over.

I told her the next morning that Annie fell asleep in my bed and thought nothing of it for the next few days.

The next time I saw her she sat me down and very seriously explained why she thought what had happened was super inappropriate, she also brought up a bunch of stuff that I hadn’t noticed. Like how she thought Annie would overstep boundaries by playing with my hair and holding my hand at a festival while my girlfriend was walking alone behind. This stuff did happen but I meant nothing by it and love my girlfriend to death. 

My girlfriend did say that I hadn’t done anything wrong because I had never initiated this, but I also hadn’t noticed that it had bothered her.

She said that the whole situation probably wouldn’t have bothered her if it weren’t for one conversation.

We have often talked about having threesomes and which of our friends we would sleep with. Obviously not seriously but we just find it interesting to explore each other’s tastes-and I said Annie. 

After her pointing this out I feel like I’m hyper aware of how I am acting around Annie and I fear it will change our friendship.

AITA for feeling that my GF blowed this out of proportion and letting this affect my friendship with Annie? 

TL;DR : My girlfriend got angry with me because my friend slept over in my bed and she thinks this friend crosses the line too much.


"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the author (21M) had a sleepover with his friend Annie (22F) in his room while his girlfriend (20F) was at a concert. They ended up falling asleep together after watching TV and smoking. The girlfriend later confronted him about it, feeling it was inappropriate, especially since they had previously joked about threesomes with Annie.

First, I need to consider the dynamics between the three people. The key points here are: the couple's communication, the boundaries in the relationship, and whether the author's actions crossed any lines. The author didn't ask his girlfriend about the sleepover, which might be a point of contention. Even though the intention was just to have a friend over, not having that conversation could be seen as a breach of trust or respect for the girlfriend's feelings.

The girlfriend was upset not just about the sleepover but also about past behaviors with Annie, like hand-holding and hair-playing, which she found concerning. The author didn't notice or acknowledge that these actions made her uncomfortable. Since they had discussed threesomes in a hypothetical way, maybe the girlfriend felt that those jokes made the recent situation more complicated. The author didn't realize the impact of his actions, which shows a lack of awareness of her feelings and boundaries.

In relationships, communication is key. The author might not have intended to hurt his girlfriend, but not considering her perspective and not checking in about boundaries could be seen as a mistake. The fact that he's now hyper-aware and worried about the friendship with Annie might indicate that he's starting to understand the issue, but the initial lack of communication and awareness of his girlfriend's signals could mean he was wrong in some way.

However, it's also possible that the girlfriend overreacted, especially if the sleepover was innocent. But the accumulation of past behaviors and the context of their previous discussions about threesomes might have made her more sensitive. The author's not initiating any of the actions but being a passive participant in Annie's overstepping might not make him entirely at fault, but he could be at fault for not being more attuned to his girlfriend's feelings and for not setting clearer boundaries with Annie. 

So, considering all that, the answer might lean towards A (the author is in the wrong) because he didn't communicate with his girlfriend and didn't notice that his actions were making her uncomfortable, even if the intention was innocent. But there's also a strong argument that the girlfriend overreacted, so maybe it's a B (not in the wrong). However, in relationships, even if the actions are innocent, not considering the partner's feelings is a mistake. So I think A is the answer here.
